questions.text: A 32-year-old man is apprehensive of general anesthesia and prefers a regional anesthetic. Decision is made to conduct spinal anesthesia for the repair of inguinal hernia, along with midazolam and fentanyl to allay anxiety. During the procedure, he suddenly loses consciousness. There is profound hypotension with a systolic blood pressure of 44 mm Hg and a heart rate of 28 bpm. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is started. The most appropriate intervention is the administration of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the setting of cardiac arrest, the ACLS guidelines recommend immediate administration of epinephrine (1 mg IV every 3–5 minutes) alongside high-quality chest compressions and defibrillation if indicated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ephedrine (Option A): Used for treating hypotension related to spinal anesthesia, but not in pulseless cardiac arrest.

Atropine (Option B): Used in symptomatic bradycardia with a pulse, not during pulseless arrest.

Flumazenil (Option D): A reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose, not indicated for cardiac arrest management.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery under general anesthesia with isoflurane, fentanyl, and nitrous oxide develops acute pulmonary edema after receiving a massive blood transfusion. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for the acute management of this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Because this patient is in acute pulmonary edema, immediate action is needed to reduce the volume overload and relieve the pressure in the pulmonary circulation. This can only be achieved if we reduce preload (amount of blood returning to the heart).
  • Nitroglycerin acts as a potent venodilator via conversion to nitric oxide, which increases venous capacitance.
  • This reduces preload by redistributing blood to the peripheral venous system, thereby unloading the pulmonary circulation, which is particularly helpful in managing pulmonary edema due to volume overload (e.g., post-transfusion).

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A) is an inhalational anesthetic with vasodilatory properties, but it does not provide rapid venous unloading in this context.

Digoxin (Option C): In this scenario, the pathophysiology is primarily related to volume overload, not cardiac contractility or rhythm disturbances, making digoxin inappropriate.

Morphine (Option D) has historically been used in pulmonary edema for its venodilatory and anxiolytic effects, but its role is now limited due to the risk of respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female posted for a laparoscopic hernia repair surgery was induced for general anesthesia with Propofol, Fentanyl and an intermediate-acting, non-depolarizing muscle relaxant. After surgery, the patient goes into delayed respiratory depression in the post-operative ward. What could be the reason for this event?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The diagnosis of delayed respiratory depression in the post-operative period is best explained by fentanyl administration.

The key clue in the question is the delayed onset of respiratory depression after an uneventful general anesthesia, suggesting a drug with redistribution and delayed reappearance in plasma.

  • Fentanyl is a highly lipophilic opioid with a large volume of distribution.
  • Initially, 75% of fentanyl is sequestered by the lungs after IV administration.
  • It is also redistributed to skeletal muscles and fat tissues, where it undergoes ion trapping, particularly in the stomach.
  • In the post-operative period, there is a delayed release of fentanyl from these reservoirs, leading to a secondary plasma peak.
  • This secondary peak can cause delayed respiratory depression, especially in sedentary, fasting post-op patients, where mobilization of the drug back into circulation is facilitated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Propofol (Option A):

  • Although propofol can cause respiratory depression, its effect is short-acting.
  • The induction dose typically wears off in 8–10 minutes.
  • Delayed respiratory depression due to propofol is not expected post-operatively unless a continuous infusion was used (which was not the case here).

Inadequate Reversal (Option B):

  • Inadequate reversal may cause immediate post-extubation respiratory compromise, but not a delayed presentation.
  • The stem suggests delayed onset, which is not characteristic of reversal issues.

Residual Neuromuscular Blockade (Option C):

  • Intermediate-acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., atracurium, vecuronium) generally do not persist long enough post-op to cause delayed respiratory depression.
  • Additionally, clinical monitoring and reversal are standard and would likely have corrected this intraoperatively.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fentanyl can cause delayed respiratory depression due to redistribution and delayed re-entry into systemic circulation.
  • High lipid solubility and large volume of distribution are critical pharmacokinetic properties contributing to this effect.
  • Always monitor patients in the post-op ward for opioid-induced respiratory depression, especially after high doses or prolonged surgeries.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male has nausea and vomiting in the post-anesthesia care unit, needing antiemetic therapy. He develops involuntary facial movements, difficulty swallowing, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with classic signs of an acute dystonic reaction, a form of extrapyramidal symptom (EPS). The presence of these symptoms following administration of an antiemetic suggests a drug with dopamine antagonist properties. Among the options listed, metoclopramide is the most potent D2-receptor antagonist, strongly associated with such adverse effects.

Because of its antidopaminergic activity, metoclopramide should be used with caution, if at all, in patients with

  • Parkinson's disease
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Those who have movement disorders related to dopamine inhibition or depletion

In patients with no known movement disorders too, dystonic extrapyramidal reactions (oculogyric crises, opisthotonos, trismus, torticollis) are known to occur

Explanation of Other Options:

Promethazine (Option A):

  • While promethazine (a phenothiazine) can cause extrapyramidal symptoms due to weak dopamine antagonism, such reactions are less common than with metoclopramide.
  • Its primary mechanism is H1 histamine receptor antagonism, with weaker dopaminergic activity.

Diphenhydramine (Option B):

  • Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine with anticholinergic and anti-dopaminergic properties.
  • It is not typically a cause of dystonia; rather, it is often used as treatment for EPS, especially drug-induced dystonia due to its anticholinergic activity.

Granisetron (Option D) Ruled Out:

  • Granisetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, used for the prevention and treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).
  • It does not interact with dopamine receptors, and hence does not cause extrapyramidal side effects.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male is undergoing emergency decompressive craniectomy for an acute subdural hemorrhage. During surgery, the head end is elevated at 30 degrees, and blood pressure is being monitored via a cuff on the right arm. In this position, how will the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) or cerebral blood flow (CBF) relate to the blood pressure value displayed on the monitor?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is defined as:

CPP=MAP (at brain level)−ICP (intracranial pressure)

MAP: Mean arterial pressure, ICP: Intracranial pressure

The MAP must be measured or estimated at the level of the brain, typically at the external auditory meatus (roughly the level of the circle of Willis when supine or slightly reclined).

In this case:

  • The head is elevated to 30°, which raises the brain above the level of the heart and arms.
  • Blood pressure is being measured at the right arm, which is below the brain.
  • Therefore, the MAP at the brain level will be lower than that measured at the arm due to hydrostatic pressure differences (roughly 2 mmHg drop per inch, or 0.77 mmHg per cm of elevation).

Implication:

  • Because the displayed blood pressure (from the arm) overestimates the actual cerebral perfusion pressure, the true CPP is decreased.
  • This mismatch can lead to inadequate cerebral perfusion, especially dangerous in cases of raised ICP or traumatic brain injury.

choices.text: Fiber-optic endoscopy to look for remnants of the tube
Pour normal saline over the field

questions.text: A 43-year-old male is undergoing a vocal cord growth excision under general anesthesia. During the laser-guided ablation of the lesion, the endotracheal tube catches fire. In the event of an airway fire, which of the following steps is least helpful?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fiberoptic endoscopy is important after initial stabilization to assess airway injury, but is not helpful during the acute management of the fire.

Steps in Airway Fire Management

Airway fires are rare but life-threatening emergencies that can occur during procedures involving lasers or electrocautery in or near the airway-especially during general anesthesia with an endotracheal tube in place. Immediate and coordinated action is critical to minimize injury and prevent complications. The following steps should be taken promptly and in order:

  1. Stop All Gas Flow: The first and most urgent step is to immediately discontinue the flow of all airway gases, especially oxygen and nitrous oxide, as they are potent oxidizers and fuel combustion. Turning off the anesthesia machine and disconnecting the breathing circuit helps eliminate the oxidizing environment. (Option B ruled out)
  2. Remove the Endotracheal Tube (ETT): The ETT-especially if made of PVC-is highly flammable and acts as a fuel source. Its immediate removal is essential to prevent further thermal damage to the tracheobronchial tree and stop the progression of the fire within the airway. (Option A ruled out)
  3. Extinguish the Fire by Irrigating with Saline or Sterile Water: After tube removal, pour cold saline into the airway to douse any remaining flames and cool the tissue. This step also helps minimize mucosal injury and prevent ongoing combustion of any residual material. (Option D ruled out)
  4. Re-establish and Secure the Airway: Once the fire is extinguished, assess and secure the airway. Depending on the situation, this may involve:
    • Mask ventilation with room air
    • Insertion of a new endotracheal tube
    • Emergency tracheostomy if airway edema or obstruction is severe
      Avoid using high oxygen concentrations during this stage unless absolutely necessary.
  5. Perform Fiberoptic Endoscopy (After Stabilization): After the patient is stabilized, a fiber-optic bronchoscopy should be performed to:
    • Evaluate the extent of thermal injury
    • Detect any residual fragments of the burnt tube or debris
    • Guide further airway management or referral to specialists

This is not part of acute fire suppression, but an essential post-event evaluation

questions.text: The Ring-Adair-Elwin (RAE) tube is a flexometallic, reinforced tube with preformed curve. The use of a RAE tube can be used in all the following indications except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The RAE tube (Ring-Adair-Elwyn) is a preformed endotracheal tube designed to direct the breathing circuit away from the surgical field, especially in surgeries involving the face, mouth, and upper airway. It comes in two main versions:

  • Oral RAE: Curves downward; commonly used for oral and facial surgeries
  • Nasal RAE: Curves upward; used for intraoral and some dental surgeries

Appropriate Indications:

  • Adenotonsillectomy: Keeps the circuit away from the surgical field (oral cavity and oropharynx). (Option B ruled out)
  • Cleft palate repair: Nasal RAE helps provide a clear surgical field. (Option A ruled out)
  • Maxillofacial surgery: Oral RAE helps avoid interference with facial structures. (Option C ruled out)

Not Recommended:

  • Thyroidectomy: RAE tubes are not ideal because,
    • The surgical field is in the anterior neck, where the tube’s curved design (especially oral RAE) may obstruct access.
    • It may interfere with neck extension and positioning.

For thyroidectomy, a standard endotracheal tube (cuffed, non-preformed) is preferred for its flexibility and neutrality in position.

questions.text: A hyperthyroid patient presents to the casualty room following a road traffic accident. He has sustained a right leg crush injury that requires amputation. He is taken up for surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following monitors is likely to indicate the precipitation of a thyroid crisis intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperglycemia may occur in thyroid storm but is nonspecific and not reliably detected by standard intraoperative monitors, making it the least helpful sign in detecting thyroid storm intraoperatively.

Thyroid storm is a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism, often triggered by stress, trauma, surgery, or infection. It results in heightened metabolic activity and sympathetic overdrive.

Classic Clinical and Intraoperative Signs of Thyroid Storm:

  • Hyperthermia (can exceed 40°C)
  • Tachycardia (often >140 bpm; may lead to arrhythmias)
  • Elevated end-tidal CO2 (reflects hypermetabolism and increased CO2 production)
  • Hypertension
  • Agitation, confusion, coma
  • Sweating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

These signs are detectable via intraoperative monitoring:

  • Temperature probes → Hyperthermia (Option A ruled out
  • ECG/HR monitors → Tachycardia (Option C ruled out
  • Capnography → Elevated EtCO2 (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is in the neurosurgical recovery ward following pituitary adenoma excision. He begins to produce a high volume of dilute urine. Laboratory investigations reveal increased serum osmolality and decreased urine osmolality. What is the most appropriate line of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with classic signs of central diabetes insipidus (DI), a common complication following pituitary or hypothalamic surgery, including transsphenoidal resection of a pituitary adenoma.

Key Diagnostic Indicators of Central DI:

  • Polyuria: High urine output, often >3L/day
  • Dilute urine: Low urine osmolality
  • Increased serum osmolality: Due to free water loss
  • Hypernatremia (may be present)
  • Sudden onset following neurosurgery suggests central (neurogenic) DI

Treatment:

  • Desmopressin (DDAVP): A synthetic vasopressin analogue that replaces deficient ADH (antidiuretic hormone).
    • Routes: Intranasal, oral, or IV
    • First-line treatment for central DI
  • Fluid replacement may be needed if significant volume loss
  • Condition is often transient post-surgery, but requires close monitoring

Explanation of Other Options:

Fluid restriction (Option B): Would worsen hypernatremia and dehydration in DI

Diuretics (Option C): Not appropriate here; they may be used in SIADH, not DI

Insulin (Option D): Irrelevant; used for diabetes mellitus, not diabetes insipidus

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with swelling in the front of the neck. FNAC revealed thyroid carcinoma, and she underwent a total thyroidectomy. Postoperatively, a fibreoptic laryngoscopic examination was performed and showed the following image of the vocal cords.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows normal vocal cords

During a thyroidectomy, particularly for malignancy, there is risk of nerve injury, especially to:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN): Affects abduction/adduction of vocal cords
  • External branch of superior laryngeal nerve: Affects pitch modulation

Vocal Cord Function Evaluation:

Post-surgical assessment of vocal cord mobility is essential to rule out nerve injury. This is usually done via:

  • Flexible fibreoptic nasolaryngoscopy
  • Ultrasound of the vocal cords
  • Asking the patient to phonate "E" or cough

Interpretation of Normal Fibreoptic Findings:

  • Symmetrical vocal cord movement
  • Complete adduction during phonation
  • Abduction during inspiration
  • No pooling of secretions or paradoxical motion

These findings indicate normal vocal cord function, meaning no nerve injury occurred.

Explanation of other options: 

Abductor palsy (Option B): Cord remains medially placed, doesn't abduct → often results from bilateral RLN injury

Adductor palsy (Option C): Cord remains laterally displaced, doesn’t adduct → often from unilateral RLN injury

Superior laryngeal nerve palsy (Option D): Voice becomes weak and monotone due to loss of cricothyroid muscle function, but cords may appear normal on routine fibreoptic scope.

choices.text: General anesthesia with depolarizing muscle relaxant
General anesthesia with non-depolarizing muscle relaxant

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a penetrating eye injury and is scheduled for globe repair. What is the most appropriate anesthetic management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In cases of penetrating eye injuries, general anesthesia with a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant is preferred, as it is essential to avoid any rise in intraocular pressure (IOP) during globe repair to prevent further extrusion of intraocular contents.

  • General anesthesia ensures:
    • Complete immobility
    • Adequate control of airway and ventilation
    • Suppression of sympathetic responses to intubation and surgery
  • Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., rocuronium, vecuronium) are used because
    • They do not increase IOP
    • They provide controlled muscle paralysis and facilitate smooth, safe intubation

Explanation of Other Options:

Lignocaine infiltration (Option A): Not adequate for deep intraocular surgery; patients may move or have pain.

Topical proparacaine (Option B): Used for minor procedures (e.g., tonometry), not globe repair.

Depolarizing agents (Option C) (e.g., succinylcholine): Known to increase IOP and risk of globe content extrusion, especially dangerous in open eye injuries.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with achalasia cardia is scheduled for Heller myotomy. During induction of general anesthesia, she experiences pulmonary aspiration. Which of the following is NOT part of the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Steroids and prophylactic antibiotics are not routinely indicated in the immediate management of aspiration.

Aspiration Risk in Achalasia Cardia:

  • Achalasia causes food and fluid retention in the esophagus due to impaired lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.
  • These patients are at high risk for aspiration, especially during induction of anesthesia.
  • Rapid sequence induction (RSI) with preoxygenation and cricoid pressure is typically used to reduce aspiration risk.

If Aspiration Occurs (Mendelson’s Syndrome):

Immediate management includes:

  • Head-down (Trendelenburg) or lateral position: helps prevent distal migration of aspirated material. (Option A ruled out
  • Immediate suctioning of the mouth, pharynx, and airway. (Option C ruled out)
  • Endotracheal intubation: to secure the airway and allow suctioning of lower airways and ventilation with high FiO2. (Option B ruled out)
  • Monitoring for hypoxia and bronchospasm: supportive care is critical.

questions.text: An end stage renal disease patient has been scheduled for renal transplant. He is on thrice-weekly hemodialysis. His blood investigations revealed high potassium levels of more than 6.0 mEq/L and he was dialyzed preoperatively, repeat potassium was 5.2 mEq/L. The drugs to be used with caution include all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Etomidate is a safe induction agent in End Stage Renal Disease patients.

Patients with ESRD require careful selection of anesthetic agents due to:

  • Electrolyte disturbances (especially hyperkalemia)
  • Impaired drug clearance
  • Potential for accumulation of toxic metabolites
  • Susceptibility to nephrotoxins

Etomidate:

  • Hemodynamically stable induction agent
  • Minimal effect on potassium
  • No active metabolites that accumulate in renal failure
  • Safe for induction in renal transplant patients

Explanation of other options:

Succinylcholine (Option A)

  • Is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker
  • Can raise serum potassium by ~0.5 mEq/L, sometimes more in susceptible individuals
  • Avoided or used with extreme caution in patients with baseline hyperkalemia
  • Safer alternatives: rocuronium (non-depolarizing)

Pethidine (Option B)

  • Metabolized into normeperidine, a neurotoxic metabolite
  • Renally excreted and accumulates in ESRD → can cause seizures
  • Should be avoided in patients with renal failure

Sevoflurane (Option C)

  • Undergoes some metabolism in the liver → can generate Compound A, a known nephrotoxin in animal studies
  • Clinical significance in humans is uncertain, but caution is advised in prolonged use and in renal-compromised patients.

questions.text: A 10 weeks old baby is being operated upon for cleft lip repair. The baby is given general anesthesia and positioned for surgery. The main goals of anesthesia involves avoiding:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Infants, especially those under 3 months of age, are highly vulnerable to hypothermia during surgery due to:

  • High body surface area-to-weight ratio
  • Thin skin and minimal subcutaneous fat
  • Immature thermoregulation
  • Evaporative heat loss during surgery (especially in cold operating rooms or under drapes)

Uncontrolled hypothermia can lead to:

  • Delayed emergence from anesthesia
  • Bradycardia and arrhythmias
  • Respiratory depression
  • Increased anesthetic sensitivity
  • Impaired wound healing and coagulation

Hence, maintaining euthermia (normal body temperature) is a key goal in pediatric anesthesia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Separation anxiety (Option B):

  • Typically develops after 6 months of age.
  • At 10 weeks, infants do not show significant anxiety upon parental separation.

Hyperglycemia (Option C):

  • Rare in infants unless receiving excessive glucose-containing fluids.
  • Hypoglycemia, not hyperglycemia, is more concerning in neonates.

Hypotension (Option D):

  • Always a consideration, but volume status and perfusion are generally well-maintained in short, elective surgeries in healthy infants.
  • Not more pressing than the risk of hypothermia in this age group.

choices.text: Tracheal rent caused by the surgeon

questions.text: A 50-year-old female undergoing total thyroidectomy with bilateral neck dissection for thyroid carcinoma is under general anesthesia and is scheduled for an elective tracheostomy. During surgery, the anesthesia monitor suddenly shows a complete loss of end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) trace. All of the following could be possible causes except:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Loss of the EtCO2 waveform on the monitor indicates that no carbon dioxide is being exhaled to the monitor. This is a critical intraoperative event and usually suggests one of the following:

  • Circuit disconnection: No gas reaches the monitor.-(Option C ruled out)
  • Accidental extubation or airway disconnect: Airway is no longer secured.
  • Kinking or obstruction of the endotracheal tube: Blocks gas flow. (Option C ruled out)
  • Tracheal injury/rent: Gas leaks into soft tissues instead of ventilating lungs. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventilator malfunction or sampling line obstruction: Prevents accurate reading.

Endobronchial displacement (i.e., ETT moves into one main bronchus) does not explain a complete loss of the EtCO2 trace as it still allows ventilation to one lung. Instead it presents with:

  • Reduced EtCO2 amplitude
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Changes in lung compliance
  • Possible drop in SpO2

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with refractory hypertension was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and is scheduled for laparoscopic adrenalectomy. He has been started on phenoxybenzamine and propranolol preoperatively. During anesthesia management, blood pressure surges can be expected during all of the following times except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla, typically producing epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, leading to episodic or sustained hypertension.

During surgical removal, manipulation of the tumor can cause massive catecholamine release, leading to sudden hypertensive crises, arrhythmias, and other hemodynamic instability. Proper preoperative alpha- and beta-blockade is essential to reduce these risks.

Periods of Hypertension Risk (BP Surges):

  • Induction of anesthesia (Option A ruled out)
    • Laryngoscopy and intubation may trigger a sympathetic surge.
  • Creation of pneumoperitoneum (Option B ruled out)
    • CO2 insufflation increases intra-abdominal pressure, stimulating catecholamine release.
  • Tumor handling (Option C ruled out)
    • Direct manipulation of the tumor is the most potent trigger for catecholamine release → severe hypertension.

Once the tumor is removed, the source of catecholamines is eliminated. Patients are more likely to experience hypotension post-excision due to:

  • Sudden drop in circulating catecholamines
  • Persistent vasodilation from preoperative alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine)
  • Intravascular volume depletion

questions.text: A 64-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension is undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) under anesthesia. The procedure has lasted for more than an hour, and the patient is in the lithotomy position. Which of the following complications is least likely in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Although the patient has a background of chronic hypertension, the perioperative risk of hypertensive crisis is low in TURP procedures. In fact, TURP syndrome, a known complication in prolonged procedures with excessive irrigation fluid absorption, often leads to hypotension due to:

  • Dilutional hyponatremia
  • Decreased plasma osmolality
  • Resulting in bradycardia, confusion, and cardiovascular collapse

Even in hypertensive patients, the dominant intraoperative concern during TURP is fluid absorption-related hypotension, not exacerbation of pre-existing hypertension. 

Explanation for other options:

Common peroneal nerve injury (Option A)

  • Occurs due to prolonged lithotomy position, which compresses the common peroneal nerve at the fibular head.
  • Presents as foot drop or sensory loss over the lateral leg.

TURP syndrome (Option B)

  • Caused by absorption of large volumes of irrigation fluid (especially hypotonic fluids like glycine or sorbitol).
  • Presents with confusion, restlessness, bradycardia, initial hypertension followed by hypotension, visual disturbances, seizures, and hyponatremia.
  • Risk increases with surgery lasting >60 minutes.

Hematuria (Option C)

  • Very common postoperative complication due to prostatic tissue resection
  • Can range from mild to significant, potentially causing clot retention and urinary obstruction.

questions.text: The most common cause of mortality associated with administration of blood is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer: 

Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is a life-threatening, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion.

It is believed to be caused by:

  • Donor antibodies (especially anti-HLA or anti-neutrophil antibodies) activating recipient leukocytes in the lungs.
  • Or biologic response modifiers accumulating during storage of blood components.

Clinical Features of TRALI:

  • Acute hypoxemia
  • Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray
  • No evidence of circulatory overload
  • Often requires ICU support and mechanical ventilation

Transfusion-Related Mortality Data (FDA, 2005–2006):

  • TRALI: 51% of transfusion-related deaths
  • Non-ABO hemolytic reaction: 20% (Option B ruled out)
  • Microbial infection: 12% (Option C ruled out)
  • ABO hemolytic transfusion reaction: 7%
  • TACO (circulatory overload): 7%
  • Anaphylactic reactions: <5% (Option D ruled out)

Although fatal anaphylaxis and microbial contamination are important, TRALI remains the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths.

choices.text: Sepsis with acute respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with chronic liver disease and osteomyelitis undergoes tibial debridement under general anesthesia. Intraoperative blood loss is 300 mL. In the recovery room, he is found to have a systolic BP of 50 mmHg and a HR of 120 bpm. ABG on 100% FiO2 shows PaO2 103 mmHg, PaCO2 45 mmHg, pH 7.3, O2 saturation 97%. Mixed venous gases reveal PvO2 60 mmHg, PvCO2 50 mmHg, and pH 7.25. Which of the following diagnoses best explains this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario suggests distributive shock, most likely due to sepsis, in a patient with risk factors (liver disease and chronic infection).

Key findings include:

  • Hypotension + Tachycardia = Shock state
  • PaO2 is normal, but on 100% FiO2 = Impaired oxygenation or early ARDS
  • Mixed venous PvO2 = 60 mm Hg = Elevated (normal PvO2 ≈ 40 mm Hg)
  • Metabolic acidosis on venous gas
  • Pre-existing infection (osteomyelitis), liver disease, and recent surgery = Sepsis risk

All of these point towards the diagnosis of Sepsis with acute respiratory distress syndrome

  • In sepsis, cardiac output is often elevated (compensatory), which increases oxygen delivery.
  • Oxygen extraction is impaired, leading to higher-than-normal PvO2 values.
  • Sepsis also causes vasodilation (↓ SVR) → hypotension.
  • In early sepsis or septic shock:
    • Mixed venous oxygen increases
    • Lactate often rises
    • Tissues fail to extract oxygen effectively (cellular dysoxia)

ARDS may develop as a complication of sepsis, although not necessarily present yet on ABG. The hypotension, elevated PvO2, and clinical context support the diagnosis of early sepsis-induced shock.

questions.text: Which of the following peripheral nerves is MOST likely to become injured in patients who are under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The ulnar nerve is the most commonly injured peripheral nerve under general anesthesia. It is particularly vulnerable due to:

  • Anatomical location: Passes superficially at the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Compression risk: Can be compressed between the bed and medial epicondyle, especially in supine or Trendelenburg positions with arms tucked or inadequately padded.

Symptoms of ulnar nerve injury usually may appear hours to days later and include:

  • Sensory loss in the 5th and medial 4th digits
  • Weak grip (e.g., weakness of intrinsic hand muscles)

Explanation for other options:

Median nerve (Option B): More vulnerable to IV infiltration or trauma in the antecubital fossa, not typically compressed by positioning.

Radial nerve (Option C): Prone to injury with arm hanging off the table or poorly positioned BP cuffs, causing wrist drop—not the case here.

Common peroneal nerve (Option D): Vulnerable in lithotomy position due to compression near the fibular head, not likely in supine Trendelenburg.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of ocular disease is undergoing a prolonged abdominal surgery under general anesthesia. Intraoperatively, his mean arterial pressure drops to 55 mmHg and remains low for over 30 minutes despite fluid resuscitation. Postoperatively, he complains of reduced vision in both eyes. Which pre-existing condition would have placed this patient at the greatest risk for retinal ischemic injury due to intraoperative hypotension?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Retinal perfusion is governed by the balance between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intraocular pressure (IOP). In patients with glaucoma, chronically elevated IOP compromises retinal perfusion. When systemic hypotension occurs intraoperatively, especially if prolonged, the already reduced perfusion pressure can fall below the threshold required to maintain optic nerve and retinal viability, predisposing to:

  • Ischemic optic neuropathy
  • Retinal artery occlusion
  • Visual loss postoperatively

Explanation for other options:

Strabismus (Option A):

  • Refers to ocular misalignment due to imbalance of extraocular muscles.
  • Has no impact on retinal or optic nerve perfusion.
  • Does not increase the risk of IOVL during anesthesia or hypotensive events.

Open eye injury (open globe injury) (Option B):

  • Associated with risk of intraocular content extrusion, especially under increased intraocular or venous pressure (e.g., coughing, bucking during emergence).
  • While critical in trauma or during emergence, it is not linked to ischemic complications due to hypotension.
  • Not relevant to perfusion-related retinal injury in this intraoperative setting.

Severe myopia (Option D):

  • Increases the risk of retinal detachment and degenerative retinal changes.
  • However, it does not inherently impair autoregulation or retinal blood flow.
  • Patients with myopia are not particularly more vulnerable to systemic hypotension–induced ischemic events compared to those with glaucoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old army officer undergoes an 8-hour exploratory laparotomy under general anesthesia. The procedure is uneventful, and anesthesia is induced via peripheral IV cannulation. A second IV line is inserted in the left antecubital fossa after induction. Two days later, the patient reports difficulty using his left hand. On examination, he is unable to oppose his left thumb and little finger, and there is weakness in thumb abduction. Sensation over the thenar eminence and lateral three fingers is decreased. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

This patient likely sustained an iatrogenic injury to the median nerve at the antecubital fossa, where it lies medial to the brachial artery and is vulnerable to:

  • Direct trauma from needle or catheter placement
  • Compression from hematoma or extravasation
  • Chemical irritation from IV drug extravasation

Clinical signs pointing to median nerve injury:

  • Motor: Inability to oppose the thumb and little finger → impaired thenar muscle function, especially opponens pollicis
  • Sensory: Loss over palmar aspect of lateral 3½ digits and thenar eminence

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A) : Would cause wrist drop and posterior hand sensory loss, not thumb opposition issues.

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Affects intrinsic hand muscles and hypothenar sensation, but thumb opposition is mainly median-innervated.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option D): Affects forearm flexors and lateral forearm sensation, not hand muscles or thumb function.

choices.text: Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman undergoes an uneventful total thyroidectomy under general anesthesia. She is extubated in the operating room after demonstrating adequate airway reflexes and spontaneous ventilation. Two days later, she develops progressive stridor and signs of upper airway obstruction. On examination, she is alert and afebrile, and her voice is normal. What is the most likely cause of this delayed airway compromise?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The most likely cause of stridor and upper airway obstruction 48 hours after a total thyroidectomy is hypocalcemia, due to parathyroid gland injury or inadvertent removal.

Hypocalcemia typically presents within 24 to 96 hours postoperatively and can cause:

  • Laryngospasm
  • Stridor
  • Perioral numbness, tingling
  • Muscle cramps or carpopedal spasms
  • Seizures (if severe)

These symptoms are often reversible with intravenous calcium administration (e.g., calcium gluconate).

Explanation of other options:

Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option A): Would cause vocal cord paralysis, either unilateral (hoarseness) or bilateral (severe stridor). However, symptoms would have likely appeared immediately post-op, and this patient has a normal voice, making this less likely.

Hematoma (Option B): Presents within hours after surgery with swelling, ecchymosis, tracheal deviation, and airway compromise. It is a surgical emergency, not typically delayed by two days.

Tracheomalacia (Option C): Rare in thyroidectomy unless there was long-standing goiter-induced tracheal compression. It typically manifests immediately after extubation, not after 2 days. No history of tracheal collapse symptoms here.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man with no previous medical history except for cataracts is undergoing a transurethral resection of the prostate gland under spinal anesthesia. Twenty minutes into the procedure the patient becomes restless. Over the next 20 minutes, his blood pressure increases from 110/70 to 140/90 mm Hg and his heart rate slows from 90 to 50 beats/min. The patient is noted to have some difficulty breathing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

During TURP procedures, large amounts of non-electrolyte-containing irrigation fluids (e.g., glycine, sorbitol, mannitol) are used. These fluids can be rapidly absorbed into the systemic circulation via prostatic venous sinuses, especially if the resection time is long or venous channels are large and open.

Clinical signs of TURP syndrome or fluid overload include:

  • Restlessness and confusion (early neurologic symptoms)
  • Initial hypertensive stage (increased intravascular volume) followed by hypotension (hypertension and hyponatremia causing net water flux out of intravascular space into pulmonary interstitium)
  • Bradycardia (reflex vagal response due to baroreceptor stimulation)
  • Pulmonary edema or dyspnea
  • Occasionally progresses to seizures or coma if cerebral edema ensues

Investigations to confirm:

  • Serum electrolytes (especially Na+)
  • Chest X-ray (for pulmonary congestion)
  • ECG (for bradyarrhythmias)

Explanation of other options:

Hyponatremia (Option B): While this can occur due to dilutional absorption of hypotonic irrigation fluid, hyponatremic symptoms such as confusion, seizures, or coma typically take longer to manifest or present more severely when Na+ falls <120 mEq/L. In this case, the presentation (HTN + bradycardia + dyspnea) is more consistent with volume overload than isolated hyponatremia.

High spinal (Option C): Would cause hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory compromise due to sympathetic blockade. However, this usually occurs within minutes of spinal administration, not 40 minutes later during TURP, and is not associated with hypertension.

Bladder perforation (Option D): May present with abdominal pain, referred shoulder pain, hypotension, or difficulty with irrigation flow, not with hypertension or bradycardia. It’s a possible complication but doesn't fit the clinical signs here.

choices.text: Hypotension with regional anesthesia at the end of the procedure
Postdural puncture headache with spinal anesthesia

questions.text: Patients who undergo extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy are at increased risk for
questions.solution:
Anesthesia for extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy may be accomplished with either general anesthesia or epidural anesthesia. When a patient is submerged in the stainless steel tub, the peripheral vasculature becomes compressed by the hydrostatic pressure, resulting in an increase in preload. Removing the pa[1]tient from the tank has the opposite effect. In patients who have received epidural anesthesia, there is an increased incidence of hypotension caused by epidural-induced sympathectomy after they emerge from the bath

Reference: Miller: Basics of Anesthesia, ed 6, p 627.

questions.text: The most common reason for admitting outpatients to the hospital following general anesthesia is
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The most common reason for unexpected hospital admission after outpatient general anesthesia—and for prolonged post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) stay, in both adults and children, is postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Other common contributors to extended recovery time include pain and excessive drowsiness, but PONV remains the leading cause requiring unplanned admission.

Explanation of other options:

Inability to void (Option B):

  • Urinary retention can occur postoperatively, particularly after spinal or epidural anesthesia, or with use of opioids and anticholinergic drugs.
  • It is more common in older males with prostatic enlargement.
  • While it can delay discharge, it is less frequent than PONV and often managed with a single catheterization rather than hospital admission.

Inability to ambulate (Option C):

  • Postoperative dizziness, weakness, or hypotension may temporarily impair ambulation.
  • This is usually due to residual anesthetic effects, pain, or inadequate hydration.
  • However, with monitoring and supportive care, most patients regain ambulation capacity without requiring admission.
  • It is a less common cause of hospital admission than PONV.

Surgical pain (Option D):

  • Pain is expected after many surgeries and is generally managed with oral analgesics.
  • Severe pain can delay discharge or require reassessment, but routine protocols for postoperative pain control (e.g., multimodal analgesia) make this a less frequent cause of unplanned admission compared to PONV.
  • Additionally, pain-related issues are often anticipated and preemptively managed, unlike unpredictable PONV.

questions.text: A 47-year-old morbidly obese patient develops bilateral visual loss (only able to perceive light) following a 6-hour prone-position laminectomy and fusion of three spinal segments. Intraoperatively, the patient received 6 units of packed red blood cells and 5 liters of lactated Ringer's solution. The mean arterial pressure was maintained between 50-60 mmHg throughout the procedure. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in the cause of this visual loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is ischemic optic neuropathy (ION), particularly posterior ischemic optic neuropathy (PION), which is the most common cause of postoperative bilateral visual loss following prolonged prone-position spinal surgery.

Key contributing factors include:

  • Prolonged surgery (>6 hours)
  • Significant fluid resuscitation and transfusion → edema, increased venous pressure
  • Intraoperative hypotension (MAP < 60 mmHg)
  • Anemia or hemodilution
  • Obesity and prone positioning

These lead to impaired perfusion of the posterior optic nerve, which lacks collateral blood supply and is particularly vulnerable to ischemia.

Explanation of other options:

Central retinal artery (Option A): Occlusion would typically cause unilateral and sudden visual loss. Also associated with external eye pressure (e.g., improper positioning with direct globe compression), which would not explain bilateral symptoms here.

Retina (Option C): Retinal causes usually result in visual field defects, floaters, or flashing lights. Retinal ischemia is not typical in this setting and rarely bilateral.

Cerebral cortex (Option D): Cortical blindness from occipital lobe ischemia would result in preserved pupillary light reflexes and denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), which isn’t described. Also, it would not be associated with prone spinal surgery in isolation.

questions.text: A patient develops signs of an anaphylactic reaction following administration of atracurium during induction of anesthesia. The episode resolves with appropriate management. Which of the following serologic markers, if measured 1 to 2 hours after the event, would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

In suspected anaphylaxis, serum tryptase is the most helpful and reliable serologic marker if measured within 1 to 3 hours after the onset of symptoms:

  • Tryptase is a neutral protease stored and released by mast cells during IgE-mediated (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions, such as true anaphylaxis.
  • It has a longer half-life than histamine and is most reliably measured within 1 to 3 hours after the onset of symptoms.
  • A rise in serum tryptase levels compared to baseline is a key diagnostic marker for anaphylaxis, helping distinguish it from non-IgE mediated reactions (like anaphylactoid responses).
  • Tryptase is not elevated in all cases of anaphylaxis, but if elevated, it's supportive evidence, especially for mast cell degranulation.

Explanation of other options:

Laudanosine (Option B): A metabolite of atracurium and cisatracurium metabolism; has no role in allergic reaction diagnosis. It may cause CNS excitation in high concentrations but is not an immune marker.

Histamine (Option C): Released during anaphylaxis but has a very short half-life (15–60 minutes), making it unreliable if measured 1–2 hours after the event.

Bradykinin (Option D): Involved in non-allergic angioedema and ACE-inhibitor–related reactions. It is not specific to mast cell degranulation and not useful for confirming anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the factors in adults listed below is the strongest independent predictor of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in most studies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is defined as any nausea, retching, or vomiting occurring during the first 24-48 hours after surgery. It is a common and distressing complication following anesthesia, affecting up to 30% of general surgical patients and up to 70-80% in high-risk groups.

Based on large prospective studies, including the widely accepted Apfel Simplified Risk Score, female gender is the strongest independent predictor of PONV in adults.

The four most significant predictors in the Apfel score:

  1. Female gender
  2. Non-smoker status
  3. History of PONV or motion sickness
  4. Postoperative opioid use

Each factor adds about a 20–25% increased risk.

Explanation of other options

History of PONV (Option B) is highly predictive but generally not stronger than female gender in multivariate analysis.

History of migraines (Option C) is associated but not as strongly predictive as female sex or prior PONV.

History of cigarette smoking (Option D) is actually protective, likely due to chronic desensitization of the chemoreceptor trigger zone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 24 weeks gestation undergoes an emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia with sevoflurane and rocuronium for muscle relaxation. At the end of the procedure, neuromuscular blockade is reversed using neostigmine and glycopyrrolate. Approximately 3 minutes after reversal, fetal bradycardia is detected on monitoring, with the fetal heart rate dropping to 88 beats/min. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the fetal bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The temporal association between administration of neostigmine + glycopyrrolate and the onset of fetal bradycardia strongly points to a pharmacological cause.

  • Neostigmine, a quaternary ammonium anticholinesterase, can cross the placenta in small but clinically significant amounts.
  • In the fetus, neostigmine increases acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, which can stimulate the fetal vagus nerve, leading to bradycardia.
  • Glycopyrrolate, also a quaternary compound, does not cross the placenta effectively and therefore cannot block the muscarinic effects of neostigmine in the fetus.
  • In contrast, atropine (a tertiary amine) does cross the placenta and is preferred when fetal effects are a concern.

Thus, the fetal bradycardia is best explained by unopposed muscarinic stimulation caused by neostigmine, making reversal agents the most likely cause.

Explanation for other options:

Umbilical cord compression (Option A): Unlikely in a non-laboring patient at 24 weeks gestation, especially during intra-abdominal surgery under general anesthesia.

Uteroplacental insufficiency (Option B): Would suggest chronic compromise; also, maternal hemodynamics are stable.

Fetal hypoxia (Option C): No signs of maternal hypoxemia or hypotension; timing after drug administration suggests pharmacologic cause.

questions.text: In a patient with compartment syndrome, which of the following signs would be the last to appear?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

In compartment syndrome, the progression of symptoms is classically described by the "6 Ps":

Pain: First symptom to appear, often out of proportion to the injury. (Option B ruled out)

Paresthesia: Tingling or numbness as nerves become compressed. (Option C ruled out)

Paralysis: Later sign, indicating motor nerve ischemia. (Option D ruled out)

Pallor: Pale skin, but less reliable.

Pulselessness: Last sign, occurs only when arterial flow is severely compromised, which is a late and ominous finding.

Poikilothermia: Affected limb may feel cooler.
